channel.title: Comments on: A Look Inside SQL Server Row and Page Compression
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Johnson
item.dc:creator: Johnson
item.description: Thanks for the sharing this great information. Here is another article related to data compression. http://www.sqlmvp.org/sql-server-data-compression/
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the sharing this great information. Here is another article related to data compression. http://www.sqlmvp.org/sql-server-data-compression/

item.title: By: Jes Borland
item.dc:creator: Jes Borland
item.description: Not necessarily - the data stays compressed in memory. What can slow things down is when modifications need to be made to pages. More information can be found at https://www.microsoftpressstore.com/articles/article.aspx?p=2225060&seqNum=4.
item.content:encoded: Not necessarily – the data stays compressed in memory. What can slow things down is when modifications need to be made to pages. More information can be found at https://www.microsoftpressstore.com/articles/article.aspx?p=2225060&seqNum=4.

item.title: By: Shmuel
item.dc:creator: Shmuel
item.description: Does compression also cause slower reads from the DB (because data has to be decompressed on each read)?
item.content:encoded: Does compression also cause slower reads from the DB (because data has to be decompressed on each read)?

item.title: By: Lelala
item.dc:creator: Lelala
item.content:encoded:
Any idea, why they came up with this 8kb thingy?
Is it because earlier in IT-tech CPUs first-level-cache was 8kb?

Regards

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Good post...using compression for a while now, I noticed that if your indexes are sorted in a certain order you can get really nice savings out of compression
item.content:encoded: Good post…using compression for a while now, I noticed that if your indexes are sorted in a certain order you can get really nice savings out of compression
